title: Mow this lawn. Learn about your brain.
description: Your lawn mowing style says more about you than you think.
byline:
By Russell Samora
& Ilia Blinderman

content.value: This is a story about how our minds work. But first, letâ€™s start with a game: how efficiently can you mow this lawn?

Just like you, most humans are actually really good at finding solutions to pathfinding problems like this. The most common example of pathfinding is the famous Traveling Salesman Problem.

The premise is simple: a salesperson must visit a set of cities exactly once and return to their starting point, all while taking the shortest possible route. We see this all the time in the real world. From a pizza delivery driver planning their stops to a trick-or-treater maximizing their candy haul, finding the most efficient routes would be solving a version of this problem.

I read a study that found humans came impressively close to computer-calculated solutions to this problem on shorter paths, and just 11% less efficient than the optimal path for 70+ stops. I was curious how well humans might perform in a similar optimization problem.
<mark>(graphic recreate their results here maybe)</mark>
In computer science, there are two main ways to tackle problems like these: algorithms that calculate the optimal path and heuristicsâ€”simple strategies for completing the task.

Algorithms solve the problem with an estimated optimal solution. But that can come at a cost as complexity grows. For example, brute force calculations for a salesperson visiting just 10 cities requires testing 3.6 million possible routes, and that number explodes exponentially as more cities are added.

Heuristics are a lot like human problem-solving; they aim for a good-enough strategy that solves the problem quickly. For example, choosing the closest city at each step isnâ€™t perfect, but itâ€™s much faster and usually close to the optimal route.
For our experiment, weâ€™ll stick with heuristics.
What type of computer-y brain do you have? Our sorting hat determined that your mowing style is most similar to the X heuristic.

We chose to look at seven different heuristics for our lawn mower game, which is a problem more formally called Coverage Path Planning. To focus on your path planning vs. technique, we simplified the world into a grid of cells.
Each heuristic follows a different approach to visit each cell on the grid. To get a sense of their general style, here are all seven heuristics on an empty grid with no obstacles.
